commentBody: From where is that picture on the top of gameplay?
Aaargh! Had a single typo that kept from a PB. Still, loved the puzzle!

A(1) 14.46
A (2) 14.45
TW 8.34
B 8.16

6020 puzzles solved
100% solved rate
755 current streak
755 longest streak

No look up

Yay for books and LIBRARY/ies!

I didn't fall into the UNPIN trap because I looked at 4D and didn't think it would end in an I. I got CALEB somehow from the depths of my attic brain because I've been to his drugstore in New Bern, NC, where he invented Pepsi. Other than that it was pretty straightforward, and gave me lots of nice mental images of sky-related things.

And yes, I want to know what that photo in the column is all about.

I used to love books but now they are defective.

If I touch the page with fingers together and widen the distance between my fingers, the print doesn't get larger.

Anybody else notice that?  How long have books lacked that feature?
Another great puzzle! Loved the books and library! Thanks!

This literary themed puzzle was right up my alley.  I was hooked at CLOUDATLAS, my favorite 21st century novel.  It is intricately structured and a tour de force of many different styles, but more than its technical virtuosity, it stands out for its compelling message on the state of civilization.  Also highly recommended are Mitchell’s  Utopia Avenue and The Thousand Autumns of Jacob de Zoet. 

I also thought it was SWEET to see a Hozier based clue.  The Irish musician has crafted some emotionally powerful songs like Take Me To Church and Nina Cried Power, the latter a tribute to the even more emotionally charged singer Nina Simone.

When’s the last time anyone actually saw a skywriter?

I was thinking about it recently. They really seem to have disappeared. A lost art. They used to be so fun to watch.

We don’t see many blimps anymore either. Every once in a while you’ll catch the Goodyear Blimp over a stadium on TV, but they’re definitely less common than they used to be.

I think my kids would lose their minds if they ever saw either one in person.
Just call me Smarty Pants! Did a Wednesday puzzle sans hints. Makes up for my struggles last Sunday.

People are gonna mad about TESLA and TULSI showing up in the same day...

Anyway, I figured out why my times are glitching. The timer is still running if I pause the puzzle, but the Statistics are properly deducting the pauses

I’m a bookworm who wanted to either be a librarian or a teacher growing up. My favorite place to be was my public or school library. In college my second year, I had a work study job as the assistant to the technical librarian and was part of the retrospective conversion (card catalog to computer) where I came across a book with all the verses to the national anthem. So, this book/ library theme was my dessert.
Loved seeing Number the Stars. There was a nice range of publication dates and reader preferences for this theme. Also enjoyed the mix of books and theater with usher and Ilsa mixed in.
I also appreciated the cross of ooh and ahh, very subtle but appreciated.
Relatively easy solve for me. Not a PB, but 5:43 better than my average.

This puzzle brings so many fun songs to mind: Hozier's "Too Sweet," BTS's "Dynamite," Muse's "Super Massive Black Hole" (even though it was used in the first Twilight movie, not in New Moon), but the one earworm that's still slithering its way through my brain comes from 8D: https://youtu.be/J5XdQ5q2PIA?si=ExitX8-y9dyAV1lT

Stop selling Kia's and Etsy.
I don't need or want commercials in my puzzle

SEA OTTER again.

We only had it a couple days ago, but here it is again.  

Don't get me wrong, I love sea otters.  I want to BE a sea otter.

I almost have to wonder if these constructor tools are causing constructors to converge on certain words and terms, over and over again.

Obviously, some of them are just useful sources of vowels, like oreo and etsy and epee.
Appropriately, today's puzzle had one of my favorite clues so far - for its lovely literary tone. 13D: "draw toward dark," for laten.

Solved it 65% faster than my average to make it my new personal best. 🤯  Dang! Really liked the theme of this one a lot!! Kind of wish it would have lasted longer. Charming, though! I liked it!

Really enjoyed 14 across, Frank account, for DIARY. It kind of works on two levels. Also, Beach blanket for SAND at 29 across, and I always love a good Princess Bride reference! 

Ah, Westley, "Death cannot stop true love. All it can do is delay it for a while." 

No excuse me while I go make myself a nice MLT.

"Do you have a hard copy of that book on meteorology?"
"No, but I uploaded it to the cloud."

(I like these puns, weather or not you dew.)

Really liked this one overall but was very puzzled by "LATEN." Draw toward dark? I'm not even sure what that means. Is that the opposite of lighten? I googled it, and it does not appear to be an English word.

Constructor Notes: "With “Cloud Atlas,” Mitchell emerged as a heavyweight of American literature."

But Mitchell is English!
Has anyone actually ever heard Covid referred to as Rona in the real world??

Loved this one. Strangely enough my daughter and her friends were just having a discussion earlier today about Twilight and whether they were Team Edward or Team Jake 🤣 I love when my life intersects the puzzle coincidentally! 
I want to add that I loved the constructor note today as well ☺️ Thank you Jared, for the lovely tribute to all of the authors. I hope to find you referenced in a puzzle one day 🤞🏼

I’m torn about this puzzle. I admire and appreciate the inspiration of the piece. 

However, it feels disrespectful to turn the tragedy of the murder of a young girl and most of her family into a clever clue. I very much wish more thought had gone into this clue. 

Similarly, in this fraught time, the term Rona gives me pause. Medical professionals are out here trying our best to maintain trust and composure, and the use of this clue also feels like it is using something important and deadly as a punchline.

The niche trivia is back with a vegence. Poor fill with non words.
A look up slog.
Such fun! A memory of great books And I was tickled to be misled by the theme revealer at 56A; I was thinking about seatbelts or turbulence or descent.
Not sure how much longer 1 down will be true.... oof

Wow! Another lovely crossword. Three in a row.

I did look up CALEB and ELWES but otherwise it was nice to see the book titles. I love the book CLOUD ATLAS too. I didn't know about OLLAS - is that a common term in US?

 For me, there was very little trivia, ie sport or rap, though if you don't know the books then ....

That was fabulous. As a committed bookworm I endorse this grid.

I’ve read all the clued books, CLOUD ATLAS a favourite, read during a holiday in swelteringly hot Portugal. Nothing to do all day but lie by the pool and read. Bliss.

I’m with Sam; TIL 1A, but wouldn’t drink his creation. In this endlessly arid heatwave I’ve been known to swig a caffeine free Diet Coke, or as my DH terms it, fizzy brown water. Cheers.

Excellent theme and revealer!
I especially like ERUDITE atop LIBRARY. 
Nicely done, Jared. 

What happens to a dream deferred?    
Does it dry up    
like a raisin in the sun?  
 
 Maybe it just sags  
like a heavy load.    
 
Or does it explode?

Excerpt from “Harlem” by Langston Hughes
I was sure the word banned in competitive Scrabble 2020 was a word similar to the answer to 61A but ends with a T.

Nice literary theme and good misdirect on the [Message from a pilot].  

I liked the crossing of BESTIE and
                                      U
                                      D
                                      S

along with two playful marine mammal clues.

I interpreted 14A. [Frank account?] completely different. Instead of seeing the question mark as something to be referring to a person (i.e. Anne Frank as Sam Corbin writes), I understood it as 'where people write "frank accounts"', as in, 'open and honest entries of events' which lead me to think of DIARY.

Would love to hear if others understood the clue this way, or even if it was interpreted in a third different way

I had UNPIN instead of UNPEG, LUFFA instead of LOOFA, and ECLIPSE instead of NEWMOON and PLUS instead of GLUT, when I went to sleep last night. My morning brain sorted it all out. I saw RAISININTHESUN off Broadway when I was young and it was deeply moving. I enjoyed this puzzle a lot. Would have loved to see BOOKWORM hidden in there somewhere.
A fun theme, but I do agree that the clue for Diary was insensitive .  I also believe the book should be read by everyone.
Thanks Jared, both for the puzzle and your notes.

Some of you might like to read “The Betrayal of Anne Frank: A Cold Case Investigation” by Rosemary Sullivan.  It reads a bit like a whodunnit although without a smoking gun to get to the answer.  In my circle, it has aroused sharp criticism of the conclusion reached by the investigators but it is a read that is, by turns, fascinating, frightening and depressing as it delves into the wretched history of the Nazi determination to wipe out a people.

Actually, my favorite clue from this puzzle was the “Message from a pilot” part of the revealer.  That was a terrific misdirect, as I kept thinking of things pilots say over the intercom during flights.

Then there was that quartet of words I love – LOOFA, ERUDITE, GLUT, LATEN – which beautified the outing.

My brain’s workout ethic was satisfied by trying to figure out the revealer before filling in a single letter, not to mention a number of no-knows.

All this was bolstered by TILs, due to some post-solve exploring:
•	OLLA.  It’s pronounced OY-yah, and is a clay cooking pot with a rounded belly, wide mouth, and often a tapered neck, for cooking stews and more.
•	HAYDN’s Surprise Symphony.  Oh, I knew that during a quiet movement the orchestra suddenly blasts a thunderous chord, but why?  One story is that while Haydn’s was conducting the piece’s premiere, he heard someone in the audience snoring, and decided to do something about it. Hah!

Thus, much loveliness wrested from the box today, making for a scintillating solve. Thank you, Jared!

A decent puzzle over-all, so take this gripe with a grain of salt - but I'm really not keen on answers like BIGMESS. While a perfectly valid phrasing, it's not really a *specific* phrase in its own right, so there's no "a-ha!" moment when you get it right. The NYT format seems quite prone to this, so maybe it's just to be expected, but I feel like good clueing / answering should give a satisfying click when solved.
Can anyone tell me the source of the picture in Wordplay?

@Barry Ancona

I don't think you saw my post on Monday where I cited recent examples of items in the tricky clues section that did not fit your version of "tricky", but were simply straightforward and hard.

Today there was another such example:
"1A. How many people knew of CALEB Bradham, the [inventor of Pepsi]? I didn’t — but I’m more of a Diet Coke girl."

I think that the deciding factor as to whether or not a chair is "sat in" or "sat on" is armrests, but it's still a close call. 

Armrests plus padding cinches it, though. You definitely "sit in" those.

I was literally blown away by today's puzzle! 
I'm not what you might call a erudite literati by any means.

Remembering a jingle from the sixties, growing up in New York City, with library card in hand:

"Who knew the library had a rally song? 'The Library Song' was published in 1967 by Joleron Music Corp., and written by Fred Hertz and Joel Herron....Here are the lyrics:
"'Oh, the place for you and the place for me is the local public library / They have books and things they lend for free, it's the latest, it's the greatest, it's the library / They have histories, they have mysteries, and for mother books of recipes / See a movie show, hear a symphony, it's the latest, it's the greatest, it's the library / Educational, informational, entertainment that's sensational / It's a way of life, it's for you and me, it's the latest, it's the greatest, it's the library.'"

A lot to like in this one! I found the theme intuitive and helpful in finding the other highlighted clues. Some clever cluing. Made me happy to be a bibliophile and library lover! 

Unfortunately about 30% of this puzzle ground to a halt for me, but a small complaint. :)

userLocation: Boston suburbs and south coast MA
commentBody: Fun puzzle and lovely inspiring constructor notes! OOH and AHH!
David Mitchell is not American - he's English

Nice puzzle, but a bit of a workout for me. All of the theme answers were familiar things, but none of them were dawning on me just from the clues. Had to work them out with some down crosses. Just made for a nice challenge and a lot of 'aha' moments when I finally had enough for them to dawn on me. Ended up being an enjoyable solve. Puzzle find today was inspired by RAISININTHESUN. ARAISININTHESUN was one of the theme answers in a Tuesday puzzle from February 20, 2007 by Jonathan Gersch. Some other theme answers: LILIESOF / THEFIELD TOSIRWITHLOVE NOWAYOUT And then... SIDNEYPOITIER Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/20/2007&g=39&d=A I'm done. ....
Odd still from New Moon?
Today’s crossword brought to you by our main sponsor, Etsy! (Again….)
I'm baffled.  What does the picture here have to do with the puzzle????

What a fun puzzle! This book person found the theme heartwarming. And the constructor mentioned at least one more book with his "Frank account?"  

Those who knew the inventor of Pepsi without using the crosses, raise your hands. Then you can pat yourselves on the back.

Some clever cluing. Sea otters and seals are always welcome.

If only the Spelling Bee would accept NONO and Gogo (and Luff, and Alee)...

Hats off to the constructor. You win a free book of your choice!

Today was solve #3000 and it was a fun one. Funny that my Achilles heel are proper nouns, then face this one for my rollover puzzle. Made it through with a couple of peeks. Specifically for SUN and ELWES. As you wish…

Happy puzzling!

Already?  Don't I remember a debut not that long since?
Well, this puzzle is lovely, if a bit easy (no doubt BY DESIGN.)  

I made a quilt that featured "The SUN, The MOON, The STARS" for a first child ...and soon made another for a second little daughter--the next generation of our Ohio BESTIEs down the road.  

Lois Lowry's book are good reads even for adults.  
I probably haven't mentioned that I "collect" Carnegie LIBRARies.  (You can read up on this legacy that continues to enrich us all.)  With modern needs, some of these treasures have been repurposed--such as the jewel box on the square in San Luis Obispo.  The Carnegie LIBRARY in Ft. Smith, ARkansas, was my first library--an imposing edifice.  I was heart-broken when told that "We don't issue library cards to Army families."  I could take as many books as I wished, but it was clear that we "didn't belong."  (And, yes, I have a card from the county LIBRARY here.)

In addition to the four themed books, the puzzle suggested a favorite of mine, the memoire/meditation *Wind, Sand, and Stars* (Fr. title: *Terre des hommes*) by Antoine de Saint-Exupéry (of *Little Prince* fame); may I recommend it. LATEN and UNPEG: Crosswordese, yes, but also examples of the continuing flexibility and productivity of the English language. When I use my time machine, I can say that I cause the day to UNLATEN? Here's some very talented young persons from California, fortunate enough to be performing in the Haydnsaal of the Esterhazy Palace: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fL3nILM6NMs Wonderful puzzle, and wonderful constructor's notes: thank you, Mr. Cappel!
Speaking of Wordle -- and we weren't -- be on the lookout for a certain word in the Crossword very soon, a la LORIS.

Well that puzzle certainly warmed this librarian’s heart. Thank you, Jared Cappel, for a midweek treat! And especially for your constructor’s note about the value of reading a finely constructed children’s book as an adult. Lois Lowry is, indeed, a master of the craft. Number the Stars is a brilliant account of the Danish Resistance for anyone who lives a good story, but The Giver is necessary reading today as we are racing headlong into a dystopian world with attempts to erase history. It’s a cautionary tale that should be required reading for everyone, young and old, before book banning empties our library shelves of all but the most innocuous. End of rant. Kudos to the puzzle.
This felt like a tougher solve than normal for me but was only 10% longer than average. A lot of guessing for me today.

A 500 day streak - Yay me! I had only one lookup, the inventor of Pepsi. Either Wednesdays are getting easier, I'm getting better at the crossword, or this one just hit my literary sweet spot. Probably a combination of practice and a good theme for me.
Under the current administration, 1 Down is no longer true, right?

I groaned aloud (with appreciation) when I solved 14 across (Frank account), enough to startle my dog.  

The answer is true both generically -- I thought "yeah, that fits" -- and more so for the specific person, Frank.  But before my brain used the proper noun as a surname I was trying to think of what five-letter word could be used as the title of a Frank Sinatra biography.  A bit far afield.
Too many proper nouns crossing which nuked the ability to solve the puzzle... Really liked the cluing but too again way, way too much trivia

I have never completely given up on Wordle.

Until today.

I think what I loved most about "Seinfeld" was Jerry's deep spirituality. In order to start every day with gratitude I watch this compilation of Jerry's prayers to the universe. "Hello, NEW MOON": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=98dai6CC5BA
The last clue I got was GLUT because I don’t know what an OLLAS is and still have no idea how LATEN is an answer for “Draw toward dark”.
This puzzle has a unique vibe, liked it a lot

I'm glad I forewent switching to Autocheck in spite of it being beyond Tuesday, when I usually need to switch. Wild guesses were fun and kept paying off; and with one lookup, the Pepsi guy, I was able to finish. I'm not sure how long it took; the 11:14:23 includes a night's sleep, breakfast, and after breakfast morning stuff including washing the breakfast dishes, but it certainly wasn't fast.
Unpeg? New to me!

When are the river otters going to get some love? I saw a NatGeo show about the Everglades the other night, and they were featured, among with other denizens of the habitat, like the roseate spoonbills, and our old friend the egret. I also learned why Marjorie Stoneman-Douglas was important enough to have a school named after her. Actually, she rarely visited the National Park she helped to create, because it was "too buggy."

Loved the puzzle. And Cloud Atlas and Number the Stars are two of my all time favorites. But having the name of a member of the current administration show up in the puzzle, seems the antithesis to the theme of thos puzzle. I do the puzzles to escape, if briefly, the current horror of  what our country is becoming.
Challenging but accessible.

"LATEN?" You mean to make later? That's a bit of a stretch but ok.

Interesting photo.

I started visiting the comments section around April, so I don't know what the comments were like during the 2021 to 2025 administration. Was the mood here always like this? Today's clues and solutions just seemed so benign to me. I honestly believe I'm a happy person. I've taken frequent breaks from reading comments, even disciplined myself to scan past most of them. I will do so again after today. When returning to the comments section, I'm reminded of the Jaws II tagline, "Just when you thought it was safe to go back in the water..." 
To better my Wordplay comments experience, should I return, I've compiled my own emu filter of such uplifting phraseology (in no particular order) as:

  - It's just sad…
  - With such a dismal outlook…
  - Given our current climate…
  - Sadly,...
  - We’re now forced to…
  - It's become a…
  - Current situation in our country…
  - It's too bad…
  - 2029 will be…
  - Can't wait for 2029

Hope this helps 😛
Now on to solving that fifth leg in the photo.

I liked it. Harder than a normal Wednesday for me, and that’s a welcome bonus. 
I’m ok with LATEN btw’s. Archaic words thrown in here and there are also a welcome bonus.
I loved this puzzle, and the constructor's notes. I'm an avid reader and have had Cloud Atlas on my TBR list for a long time. I'm going to read it as soon as I finish my current selection.
This one was quick and fun! Loved OOHS/AHH crossing
I don't mind LATEN as an answer but "Draw toward dark" could have been written better, surely.
This one seemed aimed at a very narrow age/culture group- not very fun
I was very, very disappointed to see 7D. Please do better.

Great puzzle and great constructor notes. (The picture also caught my eye; thanks Sam!)  As the husband of a middle school librarian, I loved seeing the YA books. Mr. Cappel's last puzzle, a debut on 3/11/25, was a Tuesday and was also great. This one felt more like a Tuesday to me, but he's on his way to the cycle. Good luck and keep them coming!
cdc and covid clues at this time in reality wow that's just not ok
“We made a joke clue about the holocaust and have the CDC still recommending vaccines, even though it doesn’t. We are the paper of record.”

Finished this one up earlier this morning but a busy (billable!) day prevented getting back here.  No time to go through all 313 comments now but reacting to the most recent:  

SRSLY?

[Frank account?] shows no disrespect and RONA is in the language.  

Also wanted to say that I loved the CLOUDATAS film and recall that the author was surprised it could be pulled off. 

All around first class puzzle.   

Oh,  OOHS crossing AHH a nice touch.  

Well done and thanks.
Intersecting clues regarding sounds something makes is poor construction.

I got Lois Lowry and Lois Lensky mixed up for a hot minute... Strawberry Girl fits exactly (though of course written decades earlier) and was a favorite of mine as a kid. Which made me think "Raisin, Strawberry... what does a pilot say about fruit?🧐 
Made for a funny detour but then I sorted it out.
Great puzzle! I really appreciated seeing Anne Frank and Lois Lowry as part of the clues. Their works are so essential and indeed lucky that we can get them at the LIBRARY.

Being a vibrant, strong-willed, spirited person and, well, frank (no pun intended)  as Anne Frank was, I doubt if she would be offended by the innocent reference to her diary in the clue. It was after all really her account of the horrible things that happened. I have a feeling she would not approve of us prim, prudent adults tip-toeing around delicate subjects trying not to offend anyone.  She might even laugh with Joan Rivers who had a “ 6M” tattoos on her arm yet had no qualms about making Holocaust jokes.  Per Ms. Rivers, if people laugh at something they will remember it.

Fun puzzle! A quicker solve than my average Wednesday and more smiles, until I got hung up on the same square that stalled Sam’s solve.

I looked forward to reading others talk about the cleverness of the theme (books+library+erudite+diary) and the mini-themes (oohs crossing ahs, and seals and otters being tended by vets). I was instead surprised to see sensitivity about tulsi and the cdc, and the comments in response. I tell people that commenters here (and in the Tournament of Books) are the exception to everything you hear about social media, but I guess no platform is immune. Just observing, not disrespecting anyone’s feelings.
Enjoyed this one again.  Only took 2 hours (I forgot to pause it before putting my phone in my pocket)
I am generally not a fan of sound entries but I thought the OOHS / AAH cross was pretty funny

I am currently reading A Diary of a Young Girl as a refresher to an upcoming trip to Amsterdam and only set it down to complete this puzzle before heading off to bed. I’m embarrassed to say the clue didn’t come to me right away.🤦🏻

Good, fair, tough but not horrible.
Minimal trivia.
Well done.
22D and 23D question and answers are switched. This makes 40 spelled incorrectly.  Disappointed.  Third puzzle in the last week with a major error.

@mainer

Seems to be an exhibit by Chanel at Paris Fashion Week Spring/Summer 2010

@mainer

It looks PhotoShopped. You can tell by looking at the seam above the grass (and by everyone ignoring the models).
Never mind. Google confirms what Zachary said.

@mainer

It is downright peculiar.

@NYC Traveler,

Same as Sam’s at 6D!

@NYC Traveler

I started with that too, as well as UNPin. 

Guess the i-s didn't have it today! 

It's hard to pluralize letters. 

☺️

I was thinking that the picture is of fashion floor models... And they're grounded too. 🤷‍♀️

@Francis

I've also noticed they no longer have a search function. When did that disappear?

@Beth in Greenbelt
It's there.  It's the pages in the back called "Index" (no idea why—they have nothing to o with the stock market).

@Francis

Sometimes I have to stop myself from doing that in public when I’m reading small print.

@Francis I typically read on a Kindle and have been for years, but this week I have a hard cover book and I'm embarrassed to admit how close I've come to trying to tap the page to turn or enlarge the font.

@SP
ROFL. Gonna share it with all my  techie friends. The bit at the end with "Did you read the user manual?" is priceless.
@Marshall Walthew. I haven’t read the novel but have seen the movie a few times now and think it’s great.

@Marshall Walthew

I've read and loved everything David Mitchell has written. I always recommend people read all his books in order, as there are recurring characters - although I think each is also enjoyable without having read the others.

@Marshall Walthew I was fortunate to see Hozier at Fenway Park earlier this summer on the second hottest day on record for Boston. It was wild. He played Nina Cried Power in the encore set. I love that song so much both for its recognition of her amazing catalog that speaks truth to power and also the nod to her literal screaming of the word "power" during one of my favorite songs, Sinnerman. Hozier was amazing live, but his show did not top seeing Nina herself in concert at Hill Auditorium in Ann Arbor in November 2000 (my senior year at UMich). She pranced on stage with a feather duster. None of us quite understood why, but we were AMAZED.

@Marshall Walthew also a Hozier fan and "Take me to Church" is just so haunting and gorgeous and filled with longing and emotion.

My Congregational church has an incredibly talented music director (he has a PhD in music and a large number of our soloists end up going to NYC for various Broadway roles).

One year, 100% of the music he arranged was by women composers for preludes, postludes and some other parts of the service. (Of. course we also have traditional hymns.) In another, he arranged only Americana. You get the idea...

So this past year he did audience requests (taken in advance) and he'd arrange them in wonderful ways. Was a huge hit and he did it again for the coming year.

One of the songs was "Take me to Church." Now our director has to know that the song isn't exactly a positive treatise on organized religion, but he really made it work, with our incredible bass soloist bringing down the house. 

Given that my church is about inclusivity (we voted to be open and affirming way back in 2004), acceptance, and love, it was just one more reason to love our music director and my fellow congregants.

@Eric

I think the movie is a remarkable effort to translate a novel that I did not believe to be film able to the screen.  But I agree that the book is better.

@TinyDancer

I met Hozier when he did a meet and greet after an interview and mini concert for World Cafe Live at our local public radio station. He seemed like a gracious and very modest guy.

@Striker
Join us in Oshkosh next July for EAA AirVenture. You will probably see some skywriting.

@Striker
The last time I saw a SKY WRITER was at the EAA air show  in Oshkosh, Wisconsin. If your kids are into aircraft, it’s quite something to see.
@Striker I see skywriting almost weekly where I live. And the Goodyear blimp has a home base not too far from me, so that flies over our house pretty often as well!

@Paul definitely one of the best air shows around! We also would attend the Milwaukee Air and Water Show when we lived in Wisconsin. Now yay we’re back in California, Miramar and Huntington Beach have pretty great shows. Most recently saw the one put on by March Air Force Base. My family loves a good air show!!!

@Striker

Calling the Goodyear airship a blimp is one of my new pet peeves.  While the older ones were, in fact, blimps, the airships now in use are not blimps, they are dirigibles.
@Striker Striker! Like in the movie Airplane. Apt name considering today's puzzle theme.

@Striker

We had one in the Orlando, FL area a few months ago. Can't remember what he was "writing" but the smoke was disappearing quickly so it was hard to tell. Pretty much only one letter plus the one he was working on were visible.

@Jacqui J
Weekly in Redondo Beach?! Who knew. Maybe not dead after all. I thought it might have been a regulatory deal in California airspace.

@Ken

Surely you can’t be serious.

@Doug
I think Goodyear Blimp is more of a genericization like Kleenex or Band-Aid at this point.
@Jacqui J Yes, I was going to say that if you live along the shore it’s still done for advertising and upcoming events.

@Striker

I guess not in Shawn.
@Laura Smarty pants! Or, as we say in Britain, clever trousers!
@Petrol I thought the expression used was clever clogs.
@Laura  I’d go so far as to say ERUDITE.

@Steven M.
I’ll just keep in mind that FORD and VIDKUN will probably show up in tomorrow’s mini and main puzzles.

@Nick

Since I didn’t know who Vidkun was I read his Wikipedia article, which was very interesting and sent me down a rabbit’s hole. I’m always glad when I have the time to do that.
@Steven M. I don't understand why, Musk and Gabbard were both Democrats.
@Megan if you are wondering, I became a teacher

@Megan

What grade level(s) do you teach?

@Niki B

The other day, the NYT Morning newsletter linked to a New Yorker story about our dwindling attention spans. It was kinda interesting (at least the part of it that I read).
@Eric Hougland 🤣🤣 I'll definitely check it out; thanks for the reference!

@HeathieJ

I too was an avid reader when I was younger.  Then, for some reason, I pretty much stopped.  I don't really know why, but thankfully I have re-discovered the joys of reading.  I look sadly at all the people killing time with their phones, when they could be reading.  I never go anywhere with out a book.  For me, there is something comforting about opening up a book, not knowing where the story is going to take me, but knowing I am going to enjoy the trip.  And I love turning the pages.

@Megan When I was growing up, I went to eight schools between kindergarten and finishing high school, because we moved a lot and one year I changed schools because I’d been going to the parish school but my father, in my mother’s words, “went to war with the Catholic Church” because of Vatican II. As a result, I spent a lot of time in libraries as a refuge. In the sixth grade, we had class officers for the first time in my life (at a school I only attended for half a year). To gain an office, we had to submit essays arguing for ourselves for a particular role. I wrote that I wanted to be class librarian and when the teacher announced that I’d gotten the position (I don’t recall if anyone else applied for it), I honestly thought of it as a holy duty.

@Niki B

Awww, thanks!! ☺️😍 I work in the development office at one of the colleges (focused on food, agriculture, natural resources, the environment, etc). I focus on our donor relationships and stewardship. Basically, in a lot of various ways, helping out donors know and really feel how vital they are to students, faculty, research, etc. —and what a difference for good they are making in the world by giving. I love it! 

It's a second career for me and when I left my former company of 20 years, I found this and it was like coming home career-wise. Probably too long of an answer but it's just so good to be doing something that allows me to express gratitude and make others feel great for what they're doing. ☺️

I am absolutely always amazed and inspired by our profs and students. There is just so much passion and dedication for their branches of science, sometimes so focused that it amazes me. It's delightful!  Also, one of our profs (emeritus now) developed the Honey Crisp apple!! My favorite! 

Do you mind sharing what you are a professor of?

As for finding focus, I haven't really been successful at that so far. Lately, I keep trying and retrying to read the latest book from an author and series that I completely adore... to no avail.  I like your idea of jotting notes down.  I think I'll try that! And yea, I am bad when any notification goes off, so I should just put the phone away.  

See, you professors are constantly amazing and inspiring me!!  ☺️

@Francis

Interesting theory. But even without constructor tools, I’m sure people who do this sort of thing look at each other’s work, and so certain useful words or phrases can’t help but get tucked away in the brain.

I guess the only way to know would be to lock a group of novice constructors away in solitary confinement, with no tools or examples, and see how many Utes and Enyas emerge.

I’d volunteer, but I’ve already eaten too many Oreos. (Not to mention the IPAs.)

@Heidi @Francis 

This is such an interesting theory. Somewhat related and probably more worrisome, I sadly see this with students using AI in varying ways in their writing (which as a professor and journal co-editor is something I lose sleep over.)

And it's not just overusing some incredibly annoying semi-meaningless puffed-up words when shorter words would be far better, but it's a vacuous style of writing/sentence structure that I'd only describe as the UNCANNY VALLEY (which I think is typically applied to AI images or Stepford Wife types but feels perfectly right here as well.) 

Teachers all over the world are trying to work around this issue by, say, having students write essays in class, but it's a massive problem that will likely have effects we can't fully predict or understand. Like, IDK, perhaps we will all get a little or a lot dumber, less creative, less fun, less authentic, etc.

As an optimist I can try? to hope it will lead to a pendulum swing where really good writing stands out even more against a backdrop of AI nonsense, but as a realist, I'm not at all sure that's what will happen as the number of people who appreciate good writing will also shrink.

I've taken to giving students extra points for cleverness or humor or even grammar errors because at least I know they are using their own words. 

Cheers? NB

@Francis

And one more observation. When I construct and need to a use a slightly more unusual word that’s not common to my vocabulary I look to see how often it’s been used before both in the New York Times and elsewhere. So I don’t use Etsy in real life, and it may be a popular website or not, I don’t know I just know it from Crosswords. So if I were constructing and it came up in my software for the first I’d be more likely to be reassured it was ok if I saw it frequently vs. not. So there could be a bit of a snowball effect and it may take a minute for a useful but less common word or name to start cracking into crosswordese.

@RozzieGrandma. We have these discussions now and then and I think it depends on how much in common usage the word is outside of its negative meaning. I personally would avoid COON in a crossword puzzle, even as the animal, because it’s just so much more common as a slur (I even apologize using it here as an example). On the other hand, I would have no problem with putting a SPADE as a garden implement or CRACKER as a food because they are more commonly used that way. Jim,

My contention was that "Tricky Clues" *should be* a place where the columnists help new solvers learn the tricks of solving crossword clues, and where they also might make funny (or serious) comments on clues and answers (as in today's 1A) regardless of "trickiness." 

I further contended that the columnists could not know which clues solvers would find "hard," so attempting to explain the "hard" clues would fruitless. And, unlike truly tricky clues, hard clues can be looked up. 

I did not say a "hard" clue never does or never should should up in "Tricky Clues."

@Barry Ancona

Basically your reply on Sunday was to tell me I was wrong to be "surprised this one did not show up in tricky clues".  "This one" referring to the answer "lay" for the clue "ballad".  You just said I was wrong, but never proved it.  I cited examples that could easily lead one to believe that "Ballad/lay" could be brought up in the tricky clues section.  I find your knee-jerk naysaying tiresome, and will try to ignore any such future replies from you.

Jim,

You are wrong to expect every clue and answer you deem to be hard to show up in Tricky Clues. If you can't accept that, ignoring my posts is probably a good idea.

@Barry Ancona

@Jim

I think the column should be to express what the columnist thinks was tricky OR difficult to either them or the public, it’s very personal. I agree with you, nothing wrong with highlighting a word they found unusual or difficult whether or not everyone else might agree.

I disagree.

Think of the famous photo of Sir Winston Churchill, deep in the confines of an overstuffed armchair, cigar in hand, staring resolutely into the camera lens.

Now, I am sure that there were occasions where he sat ON stools, kitchen chairs, the edge of a wall with his feet dangling, what have you, but those scenarios were not his natural element. This was not the sort of man who was prone to perching on things.

Sir Winston, ensconced, surrounded by dark red leather and the aura of power, was definitely sitting IN that chair.

No, the only way to sit ON an armchair is by sitting on one of its arms, and that is only permissable by strolling lounge singers  who stop briefly to serenade the chair's occupant...i.e., the one WITHIN it.

@M&M I was surprised you said "one of the first and few surviving, original Carnegie library buildings" because there are two within walking distance of me here in Brooklyn. (IIRC, one was in danger of being repurposed about 10 years ago, in the race to capitalize on the Barclays Center building boom. Thankfully, it survives! It's the oldest Carnegie library in Brooklyn.) So doen the rabbit hole in went... According to Wikipedia (with apologies to @MOL for the source!) and other sources, a large majority of Carnegie libraries in NYC remain extant today! https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Carnegie_libraries_in_New_York_City

I got my first library card in 1952 at the Epiphany Branch (East 23rd Street). The ADA entrance on the far right was added a few years later. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Carnegie_libraries_in_New_York_City#/media/File:NYPL_Epiphany_Branch,_Manhattan.jpg

@MOL
As a fellow former Ohioan--boy do I miss Ohio's libraries! Cleveland Public Library and Cuyahoga County Public Library systems, not to mention several smaller ones (incl. Chagrin Falls, as I recollect)--their catalogues and borrowing privileges enmeshed. My BESTIE Paul lived across the street from a Carnegie branch of the CPL.
By comparison, the (SE) Michigan libraries are a fractious bunch: The Good folk of Royal Oak or Birmingham don't want the people of Detroit touching their books; and the Grosse Pointers don't want *anyone* touching their!
And in rural Northern Michigan, where I am now? Montmorency County Library has three branches, one or two rooms each; and I doubt they employ one MLS. Still, given their resources, they do the best they can, and are invaluable to the communities, if only for their internet and e-book resources.

Two days late, but happy Anniversary! It was also my Partner's 70th.

@M&M

I don't know if the library in that was a Carnegie Library, I don’t remember one way or another,  but the town I grew up in on Long Island, Patchogue, had a Carnegie Library,  which now houses its Historical Society.

@Bill

@Bill - Love Wind, Sand, and Stars. Did you know that St. Exupery was in the U. S. to accept an award for that book when France fell to the Nazis. He couldn’t get home, so he stayed on Long Island and that is how The Little Prince came to be written here. Some years ago the Morgan Library in NYC had an exhibit that included the original manuscript. He did eventually get back to fly for the Allies but his plane was lost over the Mediterranean. The Morgan exhibit included his ID bracelet that was found in a fisherman’s net decades later. I cried when I saw it.
@Connie That was a wonderful exhibit! I love St.-Ex's writing.
@Connie This is why I come to the comments. Thank you.

@Connie  I completely agree!  I am an elementary school library specialist, and I was delighted to see that this year's Oregon Battle of the Books list includes Number the Stars.  (This means I'll be writing upwards of a hundred practice questions for it, discussing it with students, and quizzing them on its details.)  This book is on my short list of books written for young readers that I believe all adults should read *as adults*, whether for the first time or as a re-read.  I'm one book away from finishing a years-long project of reading all the Newbery winners.  While many of them are products of their time and must be extended some grace based on the prejudices of the day, Number the Stars continues to be (sometimes painfully) relevant.

I knew the word.  I thought that it might have been too obscure for them to use, but I was on Turn 4 and I had all but the eventual first letter as yellow.  One letter left from just anagramming the whole bunch.

So I played around with the letters I had, and the ones left to choose from for the missing letter, and the answer word was the only thing I could think of.  I thought to myself, I doubt this could be the answer, too niche, but I have two turns left after this, and at least I might land a few greens.  

And lo and behold, it was the word.

It gave me a 100-day streak, which should have been longer, but I missed a day.  (I did the missed puzzle late, though.)

Don't give up.

@Jerry

I think it is worse lately. There’s always a certain percentage of political comments—or especially about the political correctness of certain clues or entries—but people are even more sensitive now. I knew as soon as TULSI or CDC came up it would raise some hackles, even something as innocuous about Easter Egg Hunts on the White House Lawn engendered comments. And don’t get me started on any clue God forbid remotely related to LGBTQ. Definitely a high level of anxiety out there, right or wrong, that people sometimes need to vent on these forums (looking at you Frances). I wish it weren’t so but I’ve learned to look past it (not a reflection of any political leaning, just a reflection of my desire to use crosswords to escape from the real world not to be reminded of it).

@Jerry
No! Don’t go! I always look forward to your comments.

I know it’s tricky out there now and I understand some clues/answers may be triggering to some people. I tend to skip over those unless it’s someone whose comments I read regularly (it rarely is). 
Sometimes we need to remind ourselves this is just a crossword.

Full disclosure: one of the first comments I made, eons ago, was a horrified response to a clue that solved to Car Bomb. It’s some sort of green cocktail on St Patrick’s day?
As a Brit who lived through the IRA bombing campaign and was personally caught up in the Harrods bombing that was beyond triggering.

@Jerry

You know, it's not just you that are suffering.

I am someone you would use the "w" on.  I have been called just about every name in the book, including a D that won't and is too lazy to work.

I have worked ever since my father died when I was 11.  I mowed lawn, did yard work, until I was old enough to get a social security number, then proceeded to work through school, in power plants and as a janitor, working my way through school, becoming employed immediately out of grad school (no break year for me) until I retired at 66.

So how do you think I feel being called lazy, when I worked over fifty years of my life?  The only time I ever took any government assistance is for the few years we received my father's social security.  

So don't get me started on words the emus ought to look for, ok?
